name: Napoleon Bonaparte's Life
description: The extraordinary life of Napoleon Bonaparte (1769-1821), from Corsican minor nobility to Emperor of France, military genius, and exile.

items.name: Born in Ajaccio, Corsica
items.description: Napoleon born just one year after France acquired Corsica from Genoa. Born into minor Italian nobility. Second surviving son of eight children.
items.historicalContext: Corsica had just been ceded to France by the Republic of Genoa through the Treaty of Versailles (1768). The island was in transition from Italian to French rule.

children.name: 2. Decade 2: 1770s (Childhood)
children.description: Early childhood in Corsica and beginning of French education

items.name: Baptized in Ajaccio Cathedral
items.description: Formal Catholic baptism ceremony. Named Napoleone di Buonaparte in the Italian style.

items.name: Started primary school
items.description: Age 5, entered primary boarding school run by Beguine lay sisters as a day student. First formal education.

items.name: Sent to school in mainland France
items.description: Age 9, Napoleon and older brother Joseph sent to France to learn French before military academy. Napoleon spoke primarily Corsican Italian.
items.historicalContext: French was required for military advancement. Napoleon retained his Corsican accent throughout his life.

items.name: Enrolled at Royal Military School, Brienne
items.description: Age 9, began military education. Bullied for his Corsican accent and foreign origins. Excelled in mathematics and geography. Often isolated, became a voracious reader.
items.historicalContext: The school trained sons of nobility for military careers. Napoleon's scholarship was paid by the King.

items.name: Entered École Militaire in Paris
items.description: Age 15, transferred to elite military academy in Paris after passing final exams at Brienne. Studied artillery - considered the most scientific military branch.
items.historicalContext: Artillery was seen as the 'thinking man's' branch of the military, requiring advanced mathematics.

items.name: Father Carlo dies of stomach cancer
items.description: Napoleon's father died at age 38 of stomach cancer (the same disease that would later kill Napoleon). This left the family in financial difficulty and Napoleon as de facto head of family.
items.historicalContext: Napoleon was unable to attend the funeral due to his studies. The family's financial situation became precarious.

items.name: Graduated and commissioned as Second Lieutenant
items.description: Age 16, graduated 42nd of 58 candidates. Completed the two-year course in just one year. Commissioned as Second Lieutenant in the La Fère artillery regiment.
items.historicalContext: Youngest graduate in his class. His rapid completion was partly due to family financial pressures.

items.name: First military posting in Valence
items.people: Regiment officers, Caroline du Colombier (romantic interest)
items.description: Arrived for first posting. Lived modestly on lieutenant's pay while supporting family. Had first romantic attachment to Caroline du Colombier.

items.name: Extended leave in Corsica
items.description: Returned to Corsica on leave. Still identified as Corsican and supported independence. Admired Pasquale Paoli, the Corsican independence leader.
items.historicalContext: Napoleon's Corsican nationalism would only fade in the 1790s.

children.name: 4. Decade 4: 1790s (Revolution & Rise)
children.description: French Revolution, Toulon victory, marriage, Italian campaigns

items.name: French Revolution begins
items.description: Napoleon supported the Revolution and its ideals of meritocracy. Saw opportunity for advancement based on talent rather than birth.
items.historicalContext: The Revolution opened doors for talented officers regardless of noble birth.

items.name: Witnessed storming of Tuileries Palace
items.people: Louis XVI, Marie Antoinette, Paris mob
items.description: Napoleon was in Paris and watched the revolutionary mob storm the palace. Was horrified by the violence and the weakness of the King. Reportedly said 'If I were king, this rabble would not be here.'
items.historicalContext: This event marked the effective end of the French monarchy.

items.name: Bonaparte family flees Corsica
items.people: Letizia Bonaparte, all siblings, Pasquale Paoli
items.description: After falling out with Paoli over support for France, the Bonaparte family was forced to flee Corsica. Their home was ransacked. Napoleon became fully French from this point.
items.historicalContext: Paoli had declared the Bonapartes traitors to Corsica.

items.name: Victory at Siege of Toulon - promoted to Brigadier General
items.people: British forces, Paul Barras, Augustin Robespierre
items.description: Age 24, Napoleon's artillery plan recaptured Toulon from the British. His first major military victory. Promoted from Captain to Brigadier General - meteoric rise.
items.historicalContext: This victory brought Napoleon to the attention of the revolutionary government.

items.name: Crushed royalist uprising - 'Whiff of Grapeshot'
items.people: Paul Barras, royalist insurgents, Directory government
items.description: Napoleon used artillery to disperse 30,000 royalist insurgents threatening the government. Famous 'whiff of grapeshot' - killed about 300. Promoted to Commander of the Army of the Interior.
items.historicalContext: This made Napoleon the savior of the Republic and a major political figure.

items.name: Married Joséphine de Beauharnais
items.description: Age 26, married the 32-year-old widow with two children. A passionate but turbulent relationship. Joséphine was the former mistress of Barras. Napoleon was deeply in love; she was more pragmatic.
items.historicalContext: Joséphine's connections helped Napoleon's career. She would become Empress of France.

items.name: Italian Campaign begins - stunning victories
items.people: Austrian and Piedmontese armies, French soldiers
items.description: Two days after his wedding, Napoleon took command of the ragged Army of Italy. Won spectacular victories at Montenotte, Lodi, Arcole, and Rivoli. Made himself wealthy and famous.
items.historicalContext: These campaigns established Napoleon's reputation as a military genius.

items.name: Egyptian Campaign - Battle of the Pyramids
items.people: Mamluk warriors, French scientists, British Navy
items.description: Led expedition to Egypt to threaten British India. Won Battle of the Pyramids but Nelson destroyed his fleet at the Nile. Brought 167 scientists - discovered Rosetta Stone.
items.historicalContext: Though militarily inconclusive, the expedition had huge cultural impact on Egyptology.

items.name: Coup of 18 Brumaire - seized power as First Consul
items.people: Sieyès, Talleyrand, Lucien Bonaparte, Directory members
items.description: Age 30, Napoleon overthrew the Directory government in a coup. Became First Consul - effectively dictator of France. His brother Lucien saved the day when soldiers hesitated.
items.historicalContext: End of the French Revolution. Beginning of the Napoleonic era.

children.name: 5. Decade 5: 1800s (Emperor)
children.description: Crowned Emperor, reformed France, military conquests across Europe

items.name: Victory at Battle of Marengo
items.description: Nearly lost the battle before Desaix's counterattack saved the day. Desaix was killed. Victory secured Napoleon's political position.

items.name: Concordat with the Pope
items.description: Agreement with the Catholic Church healing the rift caused by the Revolution. Religion tolerated but under state control. Shrewd political move.
items.historicalContext: Napoleon saw religion as a tool for social control: 'Religion is what keeps the poor from murdering the rich.'

items.name: Napoleonic Code enacted
items.description: The Civil Code - Napoleon's most lasting achievement. Unified French law, enshrined equality before the law, property rights, and secular marriage. Still the basis of law in many countries.
items.historicalContext: Napoleon said: 'My true glory is not to have won forty battles... what will live forever is my Civil Code.'

items.name: Crowned Emperor of the French
items.people: Pope Pius VII, Joséphine Bonaparte, French nobility
items.description: Age 35, crowned himself Emperor in the presence of the Pope. Famously took the crown from the Pope's hands and placed it on his own head. Joséphine crowned Empress.
items.historicalContext: Painting by David immortalized the scene (though inaccurately).

items.name: Victory at Battle of Austerlitz - 'Battle of Three Emperors'
items.people: Tsar Alexander I, Emperor Francis II, French marshals
items.description: Napoleon's greatest victory. Defeated combined Russian and Austrian armies. Masterful deception and tactics. Fought on first anniversary of coronation.
items.historicalContext: Often considered the most tactically perfect battle in history.

items.name: Crushed Prussia at Jena-Auerstedt
items.description: Destroyed Prussian military power in a single day. Marshal Davout's corps defeated the main Prussian army while outnumbered 2:1. Napoleon entered Berlin.

items.name: Treaty of Tilsit with Tsar Alexander
items.people: Tsar Alexander I, King Frederick William III
items.description: Met the Tsar on a raft in the middle of the Niemen River. Created alliance with Russia. Napoleon at the height of his power - master of continental Europe.
items.historicalContext: Prussia humiliated, reduced to a minor power.

items.name: Spanish Ulcer begins
items.people: Spanish rebels, Joseph Bonaparte, British forces
items.description: Napoleon placed his brother Joseph on Spanish throne, sparking brutal guerrilla war. Would drain 300,000 French troops. 'The Spanish ulcer destroyed me.'
items.historicalContext: The first major crack in Napoleon's empire.

items.name: Divorced Joséphine
items.description: Devastated Joséphine by divorcing her after 13 years because she could not produce an heir. 'I still love you, but in politics there is no heart, only head.'

children.name: 6. Decade 6: 1810s (Fall & Exile)
children.description: Russian disaster, defeats, exile to Elba, Hundred Days, final exile

items.name: Married Marie Louise of Austria
items.people: Marie Louise, Emperor Francis I of Austria
items.description: Age 40, married the 18-year-old Austrian princess. Political marriage to cement alliance with Austria. She would give him the heir Joséphine could not.
items.historicalContext: Napoleon had defeated Austria multiple times; now he married into their dynasty.

items.name: Birth of Napoleon II - King of Rome
items.description: Napoleon's only legitimate son born. Given title 'King of Rome'. Napoleon ecstatic - finally had an heir. The boy would never rule.
items.historicalContext: Napoleon II would die at 21 of tuberculosis, never knowing power.

items.name: Invasion of Russia - catastrophic retreat from Moscow
items.people: Tsar Alexander I, Grande Armée, Marshal Ney
items.description: Led 600,000 men into Russia. Took Moscow but Tsar refused peace. Fire destroyed the city. Forced to retreat in brutal winter. Only 100,000 survived. Beginning of the end.
items.historicalContext: Largest military disaster in history at that time.

items.name: Defeated at Battle of Leipzig - 'Battle of Nations'
items.description: Largest battle in history until WWI (500,000+ soldiers). Napoleon decisively defeated by united European coalition. Forced to retreat to France.

items.name: First abdication - exiled to Elba
items.people: Coalition powers, French marshals, Marie Louise
items.description: Paris fell. Marshals refused to fight. Napoleon abdicated after possible suicide attempt. Exiled to Elba as sovereign of tiny island. Marie Louise and son sent to Austria.
items.historicalContext: Bourbons restored to French throne.

items.name: Escaped from Elba - The Hundred Days begins
items.people: 1,000 loyal soldiers, French army, Louis XVIII
items.description: Escaped with 1,000 men and landed in France. Army sent to stop him defected. 'Soldiers, I am your Emperor!' Louis XVIII fled. Napoleon took Paris without a shot.
items.historicalContext: One of history's most dramatic comebacks.

items.name: Final defeat at Battle of Waterloo
items.people: Duke of Wellington, Marshal Blücher, Imperial Guard
items.description: Final battle. Defeated by British under Wellington and Prussians under Blücher. Imperial Guard broken. 'The Guard dies, it does not surrender!' Napoleon's last gamble failed.
items.historicalContext: Ended 23 years of nearly continuous war in Europe.

items.name: Second abdication - surrendered to British
items.description: Abdicated for the second time after exactly 100 days. Surrendered to British, hoping for asylum in England. Instead, exiled to remote St. Helena.

items.name: Arrived at St. Helena - final exile
items.people: Sir Hudson Lowe (jailer), Las Cases, Bertrand, Montholon
items.description: Exiled to tiny volcanic island in the South Atlantic, 1,200 miles from any land. Spent final years dictating memoirs and shaping his legend.
items.historicalContext: The British chose the most remote spot possible to prevent another escape.

children.name: 7. Decade 7: 1820s (Death & Legacy)
children.description: Death on St. Helena and the birth of the Napoleonic legend

items.name: Died on St. Helena
items.description: Died at age 51, probably of stomach cancer (same disease that killed his father). Last words reportedly 'France, army, head of the army, Joséphine.' Buried on St. Helena.
items.historicalContext: Some theories suggest arsenic poisoning, but cancer is most accepted.

hyperedges.name: Major Battles
hyperedges.label: Military Victories & Defeats
hyperedges.description: Napoleon's major military engagements - from Toulon to Waterloo

hyperedges.name: Loves of His Life
hyperedges.label: Romantic Relationships
hyperedges.description: Napoleon's marriages and romantic life - Joséphine was his great love, Marie Louise a political necessity

hyperedges.name: Exiles & Escapes
hyperedges.label: Forced from Power
hyperedges.description: Pattern of exile throughout Napoleon's life - from Corsica to St. Helena

hyperedges.name: Seizures of Power
hyperedges.label: Political Coups
hyperedges.description: Napoleon's dramatic seizures and reclamations of power

hyperedges.name: Lasting Reforms
hyperedges.label: Building Modern France
hyperedges.description: Napoleon's enduring administrative and legal reforms - more lasting than his conquests

hyperedges.name: Family Connections
hyperedges.label: Bonaparte Dynasty
hyperedges.description: Napoleon's family - from Corsican origins to placing relatives on thrones across Europe

hyperedges.name: Fatal Overreach
hyperedges.label: Hubris & Downfall
hyperedges.description: The disasters caused by Napoleon's overconfidence - Spain and Russia drained his empire
